commentBody: In football, as in all societal endeavors, we want to shave points from those who perform best. Take this from a University of Utah grad who cheers for Alex Smith and the Chiefs. Alex Smith, a former Utah Ute, is great. No doubt. And I was rooting for him and the Chiefs tonight. But when it comes to greatness, I must sweep away my bias to see true greatness. And Tom Brady is a great quarterback. If you can put passes on the money, or numbers, it doesn't matter how inflated or deflated the ball is. It just is. And you are just you. And Tom Brady is perhaps the greatest quarterback I've ever witnessed.

replies.commentBody:
Please tell us who you've seen! Without knowing that, describing Brady as "perhaps" the "greatest" QB you've seen has no frame of reference!

Did you ever watch the greats of yesteryear?

Johnny Unitas immediately comes to mind! He was an amazing passer, kept on ticking after major hits, and repeatedly executed exciting, brilliant 2-minute drills, and last minute drives--and did it an era where QBs--not the "offensive" coordinator--called the plays!

Or, how about several other superb QBs-- did you ever see them in action?

Bart Starr,

Roger Staubach,

Y.A. Tittle,

Fran Tarkenton,

Norm Van Brocklin,

Roman Gabriel, and

Otto Graham?

Or, more recently:

Dan Marino,

Joe Montana?

Just glad that you wrote "perhaps", but if you never saw these other guys play, when they really were in command and not mere technicians carrying out orders, you really missed great football and seeing several of the greatest quarterbacks that ever played the game!

Smith played well and had numerous third down, high pressure conversions but he is at best a mediocre long ball threat AND he was saddled with the infamous Andy Reid "Clock? They use a game clock?" approach to time management.

Lets be honest. Most of the guys you mention wouldn't be drafted today and if they were would be unlikely to make a team. Todays players are significantly faster, stronger and the offensive/defensive plans are far more complicated.

Marino and Montana are close enough to the modern era that they might have good careers that would compare to Brady. But I wouldn't bet a lot on it.
